choices.text: Increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis
Decreased uptake by adrenal glands and kidney

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with prostate cancer is being investigated. The bone scan is reported as a super scan with increased uptake in the bones and reduced activity in the kidney and soft tissue. What is the reason for this super scan appearance? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis

 

Explanation:

 

The super scan appearance is due to increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis.

 

On a bone scan, a generalized increase in skeletal uptake relative to soft tissue and absent or faint renal activity. This is referred to as a super scan.

 

 

  • All the bones show diffusely increased uptake whereas kidneys are not visualized.
  • Seen with-
    1. Metabolic bone diseases
    2. Diffuse Sclerotic bone metastasis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased uptake by carcinoma prostate: While the primary prostate carcinoma may cause metastases, the increased uptake seen in a super scan specifically refers to bone metastases, not the primary tumor itself.

 

Option C. Increased uptake by the bone: This option is too general and does not specify the underlying cause, which in the context of a super scan is typically metastatic disease.

 

Option D. Decreased uptake by adrenal glands and kidney: This choice misrepresents the scenario, as the decreased visualization of kidneys is a result of the intense skeletal uptake overshadowing other areas, not due to decreased uptake by these organs themselves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A bone scan super scan appearance in a patient with known malignancy such as prostate cancer usually indicates extensive bone metastasis, necessitating aggressive management and treatment planning to address widespread disease.

questions.text: An image of a perianal disease is shown. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Fistula in Ano


The correct diagnosis is Fistula in Ano. A fistula in ano is an abnormal connection between the interior of the anal canal and the perianal skin. It often presents as a recurrent swelling or abscess near the anal verge, which may drain spontaneously. The key clues include the location of the swelling near the anal verge and the history of recurrent discharge, making it characteristic of a fistula in ano.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pilonidal Sinus: A pilonidal sinus is typically found in the upper part of the natal cleft, far from the anal verge, and is associated with hair follicles in the gluteal region. It commonly affects young men with a hairy back and is located above the coccyx, not near the anus. The key distinction is the location; pilonidal sinuses are not found at the anal verge but higher up in the gluteal cleft.

 

 

Option C. Fissure in Ano: A fissure in ano is a linear tear in the lining of the anus, usually caused by trauma or hard stools. It presents with pain during defecation and bright red bleeding but not with a swelling or external opening as seen in fistula in ano. There may be a hypertrophic skin tag covering it (Sentinel pile). Fissures do not have a history of recurrent discharge or a swelling appearance near the anal verge.

 

 

Option D. Hemorrhoids: Hemorrhoids are swollen blood vessels in the rectum or anus and typically present with painless bleeding, itching, and swelling inside the anal canal or at the anal verge. They do not present with the external openings, recurrent abscesses, or discharging sinuses characteristic of fistula in ano.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Fistula in Ano should be considered when there is a history of recurrent swelling, abscess formation, or discharge near the anal verge. It is distinguished from pilonidal sinus by its lower location near the anal canal, as opposed to pilonidal sinuses that occur higher up in the natal cleft.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child presented with fever, fatigue and left ventricular dysfunction. He underwent a cardiac biopsy (image shown). Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lymphocytic myocarditis

 

The clinical presentation of fever, fatigue, and left ventricular dysfunction in a young child, along with the histopathological image from the cardiac biopsy, is suggestive of lymphocytic myocarditis.

 

Lymphocytic Myocarditis:

 

  • Pathology: Characterized by interstitial inflammation with a predominance of lymphocytes. The image provided shows myocardial fibers with an interstitial infiltrate primarily composed of lymphocytes. Associated myocyte necrosis
  • Etiology: Commonly caused by viral infections such as coxsackievirus, adenovirus, and parvovirus B19.
  • Clinical Features: Patients may present with signs and symptoms of heart failure, arrhythmias, and systemic symptoms like fever and fatigue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute rheumatic fever: Typically shows Aschoff bodies with Anitschkow cells on biopsy, which are not present in the provided image.

 

Option C. Chagas disease: Caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, characterized by amastigotes in myocardial cells, often with mixed inflammatory infiltrate, not just lymphocytes.

 

Option D. Pyogenic myocarditis: Characterized by the presence of neutrophils, indicating bacterial infection, which is not seen in the provided image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lymphocytic myocarditis is indicated by the presence of lymphocytic infiltration in the myocardium and is commonly associated with viral infections. The clinical presentation includes heart failure symptoms, fever, and fatigue.

 

 

Lymphocytic myocarditis

 

 

Hypersensitivity myocarditis

 

 

Giant cell myocarditis

 

 

Myocarditis of Chagas disease (arrow showing trypanosomes)

questions.text: A 32-year-old man visits your clinic with his 2-year-old son, expressing concerns about vaccinations due to a belief in his community that vaccinations can lead to impotency. He is fearful for his son's future but is also influenced by societal beliefs. Addressing his concerns requires overcoming which type of barrier? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cultural barrier

 

The wrong belief of vaccination leading to impotency is an example of cultural barrier. Cultural barrier includes illiteracy, knowledge and understanding, customs, beliefs, religion, economic and social class differences, language variations, and cultural difficulties.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Psychological barrier occurs due to emotional disturbances, levels of intelligence, language or comprehension difficulties.

 

Option B. Environmental barriers include noise, congestion etc. in the external environment which hampers understanding and communication.

 

Option C. Physiological barriers include difficulties in hearing, expression, vision etc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cultural beliefs can significantly influence health decisions, and understanding these beliefs is crucial for effective healthcare communication and intervention.

choices.text: Clindamycin 600 mg intravenously 8 hourly for 7 days
Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg intravenously at 12 and 24 hours, followed by daily once

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of high fever for 5 days and altered sensorium. On further probing, it was found that he had two seizures one day ago. Peripheral smear shows the following findings. How will you manage this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg intravenously at 12 and 24 hours, followed by daily once

 

A Giemsa-stained peripheral blood smear shows many red blood cells (RBCs) infected with classic, ring-shaped and headphone-shaped trophozoites of Plasmodium falciparum parasite. High degree of parasitemia and RBCs infected with two or more trophozoites were seen, a finding typical of P. falciparum malaria.

 

Cerebral malaria is a complicated form of malaria associated with multisystem organ dysfunction and high degree of morbidity and mortality. These patients often present with impaired consciousness, delirium and convulsions. It is a medical emergency where prompt diagnosis and early institution of treatment can be lifesaving. Intravenous quinine or artesunate are the mainstays of treatment in cerebral malaria.

 

Management of Cerebral Malaria:

 

  • Artesunate: Administered intravenously at a dose of 2.4 mg/kg immediately, followed by 2.4 mg/kg at 12 and 24 hours, and then once daily if necessary.
  • Alternative Treatment:
    • Artemether: 3.2 mg/kg intramuscularly initially, followed by 1.6 mg/kg once daily.
    • Quinine dihydrochloride: 20 mg of salt/kg infused over 4 hours, followed by 10 mg of salt/kg infused over 2-8 hours.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Doxycycline 100 mg intravenously for 7 days: Doxycycline is not the first-line treatment for severe malaria. It is typically used as a secondary prophylactic measure or in combination with other antimalarial drugs.

 

Option B. Clindamycin 600 mg intravenously 8 hourly for 7 days: Clindamycin is not used for the treatment of malaria. It is an antibiotic that is used for bacterial infections.

 

Option D. Chloroquine intramuscularly 8 hourly for 3 days: Chloroquine is ineffective against Plasmodium falciparum due to widespread resistance. It is also not suitable for treating severe or cerebral malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebral malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum is a medical emergency requiring prompt treatment with intravenous artesunate, which is the most effective and rapid-acting medication for severe malaria.

questions.text: Which of the following options is incorrectly matched? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cystocele - Colposuspension

 

Anterior colporrhaphy is performed for cystocele.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

For cystocele, the appropriate surgical management is anterior colporrhaphy, not colposuspension.

questions.text: A patient presented with jaw swelling and weight loss. Suspecting a malignancy, the submandibular gland was resected. Which is the most likely nerve to be damaged during submandibular gland resection?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lingual nerve

 

Lingual Nerve: This is the branch of mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, V3. It runs close to the submandibular gland and is therefore at risk during submandibular gland surgery.

 

Sensory Distribution: Provides general sensory (pain, temperature, touch) to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. (Note: Taste sensation for this region is carried by the chorda tympani nerve, which joins the lingual nerve for a short course.)

 

Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of general sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

 

 

Injury:

 

Because dissection of the submandibular duct from the nerve is required during submandibular gland resection, the lingual nerve is at risk of injury. It is also linked to the submandibular ganglion, which will expose the nerve within the operating field.

 

The symptoms of lingual nerve injury differ depending on whether the lesion is proximal or distal to the point where it is joined by the chorda tympani nerve.

 

  • Proximal injury: There is loss of sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, gingivae, oral mucosa, lower lip, and chin.
  • Distal injury: In addition to features of proximal injury, secretion from the salivary glands below the oral fissure and taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is also lost.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nerve to Mylohyoid: This nerve is a branch of the inferior alveolar nerve (which is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, V3). It descends on the medial surface of the mandible in the mylohyoid groove.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Supplies the mylohyoid muscle and the anterior belly of the digastric muscle.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Weakness in the elevation of the hyoid bone and floor of the mouth during swallowing and speech.

 

Option B. Inferior Alveolar Nerve: It's a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, V3. It enters the mandibular foramen and runs through the mandibular canal.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Does not directly supply any muscles.
  • Sensory Distribution: Provides sensation to the mandibular teeth, lower lip, and chin.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Option D. Hypoglossal Nerve (12th Cranial Nerve): This cranial nerve exits the skull via the hypoglossal canal and supplies the muscles of the tongue.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Supplies almost all the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue except the palatoglossus (which is innervated by the vagus nerve).
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Tongue deviation to the side of the lesion due to weakened tongue muscles on that side. If you asked the patient to protrude their tongue, it would point towards the side of the injury.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which type of mutation results in the reversal to the wild type of phenotype when the mutant gene is suppressed? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mutation of tRNA

 

The correct answer is Mutation of tRNA. A suppressor mutation, specifically a tRNA mutation, can reverse the effect of an earlier mutation that produced a premature stop codon. In this scenario, the tRNA undergoes a mutation that allows it to recognize the stop codon (UAA in this case) as if it were a normal codon (e.g., serine's codon UCA). This suppressor tRNA can then insert an amino acid at the site of the stop codon, allowing protein synthesis to continue. This compensates for the earlier mutation that would have led to a truncated, non-functional protein, thereby restoring the wild-type phenotype.

 

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frameshift mutation of coding gene: This type of mutation typically disrupts the reading frame of the gene, leading to widespread changes in the amino acid sequence from the point of mutation onward. It usually results in a non-functional protein and does not suppress the effects of another mutation.

 

Option B. Addition of another normal gene: While adding a normal gene might help correct a phenotype by introducing a functional version of the gene, it does not qualify as a suppressor mutation. This option does not specifically address the reversal of a mutation at the molecular level in the same way as tRNA mutation does.

 

Option C. Deletion of the mutant gene: Deleting the mutant gene would remove the mutation but would not revert the phenotype to wild type by itself. It eliminates the gene's effect entirely rather than compensating for the mutation within the gene or another gene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suppressor mutations, particularly those in tRNA, can reverse the effects of a previous mutation by allowing protein synthesis to continue even when a premature stop codon is present, thereby restoring the normal (wild-type) phenotype.

choices.text: Collarette scale - Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea

questions.text: A young male, aged 24, has presented with asymptomatic scaly skin lesions on his back, symmetrically distributed. The provided images showcase the lesions. Can you identify the pattern of these skin lesions & the specific disease? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Collarette scale - Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea

 

Given clinical scenario and images showing Collarette scale (Herald patch) and Christmas tree pattern distributed lesions, points to a diagnosis of Pityriasis rosea.

 

PITYRIASIS ROSEA

 

  • Acute: Self-limiting (6-12 weeks) disease.
  • Etiology: Most common viral trigger is HHV 7.
  • Asymptomatic >> mild pruritus may be present.
  • Features:
    • 1st lesion: Herald patch / mother patch 1-2 weeks later.
    • Secondary lesions: Scaly papules → oval annular plaques → mild pigmentary changes → fades slowly in 6-12 weeks.
  • Distribution of Lesions: Christmas tree pattern (Downwards & outwards from the spine along the lines of Langer).
  • Treatment: Counsel, self-limiting 6-12 weeks.

 

Other Options

 

Option B: Wickham’s striae - Lichen Planus

 

  • Incorrect: Lichen Planus is characterized by pruritic, purple, polygonal papules and plaques. Wickham’s striae are white, lacy lines seen on the surface of lesions, typically not featuring a Christmas tree pattern.

 

 

Option C: Christmas tree pattern - Lichen Planus

 

  • Incorrect: While Lichen Planus can have a wide distribution, it does not typically display a Christmas tree pattern, which is specifically associated with Pityriasis rosea.

 

Option D: Wornoff ring – Seborrheic Dermatitis

 

  • Incorrect: Seborrheic Dermatitis typically presents with oily, scaly patches on the scalp, face, and other sebaceous areas, not as a Christmas tree pattern on the back.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of Pityriasis rosea is primarily based on the characteristic appearance and distribution of the rash, with the herald patch and subsequent Christmas tree pattern being hallmark features. Awareness of this pattern and the self-limiting nature of the disease helps in reassuring patients and managing expectations regarding the course of the condition

questions.text: A patient comes after 6 months of vaginal delivery with an episiotomy repair with pain at the site of episiotomy which increases during her periods. On palpation, a nodular lesion is felt. The probable diagnosis is? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endometriosis

 

The patient presents with pain at the episiotomy site that worsens during her menstrual periods, along with a palpable nodular lesion. This is a classic presentation of scar endometriosis, a condition where endometrial tissue is implanted in the scar tissue of an episiotomy or caesarean section. The ectopic endometrial tissue responds to hormonal changes during the menstrual cycle, leading to cyclical pain, swelling, and sometimes bleeding at the site, which explains the patient's symptoms. Scar endometriosis often requires surgical excision for treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Retained suture: While retained sutures can cause pain, they do not cause cyclic pain associated with menstrual periods and typically do not present as a nodular lesion that grows or bleeds during menstruation.

 

Option C. Inclusion cyst: An inclusion cyst may form at the site of an episiotomy scar but would not be associated with cyclic pain or changes during the menstrual period. Inclusion cysts are usually painless unless infected.

 

Option D. Melanoma: Melanoma would not typically present with cyclic pain related to menstruation. It is usually a pigmented lesion that may change in size or color, rather than one that causes cyclic bleeding and pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scar endometriosis should be suspected when there is cyclic pain and a nodular lesion at the site of an episiotomy or surgical scar, especially if symptoms correlate with menstrual periods.

questions.text: A female patient with infertility presented to the clinic and underwent karyotyping. What is the likely diagnosis in the karyotype shown? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Turner syndrome

 

The karyotype image shows 45 chromosomes with a single X chromosome and no second sex chromosome, confirming a 45, XO karyotype, which is characteristic of Turner syndrome.

 

Turner syndrome is a condition caused by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome, leading to the absence of one X chromosome. This genetic abnormality is commonly associated with infertility, short stature, webbed neck, and a variety of other clinical features.

 

Turner syndrome is a common cause of primary amenorrhea due to ovarian dysgenesis (underdeveloped ovaries), which leads to hormonal imbalances that prevent normal menstruation and fertility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Down syndrome: Down syndrome, or trisomy 21, is characterized by an extra chromosome 21, resulting in 47 chromosomes. It is associated with intellectual disability, distinctive facial features, and other health complications, not infertility related to the absence of an X chromosome.

 

Option C. Klinefelter syndrome: Klinefelter syndrome occurs in males with a 47, XXY karyotype. Patients typically have an extra X chromosome and may present with infertility, gynecomastia, and tall stature. It does not occur in females and does not present as 45, XO.

 

Option D. Edward syndrome: Edward syndrome, or trisomy 18, is characterized by an extra chromosome 18, leading to 47 chromosomes. It presents with severe developmental delays and congenital abnormalities. It is unrelated to the XO karyotype seen in Turner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by a 45, XO karyotype, where there is a complete or partial absence of the second X chromosome, leading to infertility, primary amenorrhea, and other characteristic features.

questions.text: Quadruple testing is done during? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 15-20 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Quadruple testing, also known as the quadruple screen or quad screen, is typically performed between 15-20 weeks of pregnancy, with the most accurate results obtained between 16-18 weeks. The test measures four serum analytes:

 

  • Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP)
  • Unconjugated estriol (uE3)
  • Free Beta-hCG
  • Inhibin-A

 

This test helps assess the risk of certain chromosomal abnormalities such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21) and trisomy 18, as well as neural tube defects. The quad screen has a lower sensitivity compared to the first trimester combined screening (which includes nuchal translucency and dual marker screening), making it particularly useful for women who present for prenatal care later in pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 9-11 weeks: This timeframe is generally used for first trimester screening tests, such as the combined screening, which includes nuchal translucency and the dual marker test (free β-hCG and PAPP-A).

 

Option B. 12-14 weeks: This period is also used for the combined first trimester screening but is not appropriate for the quad screen.

 

Option D. 22-28 weeks: This period is outside the recommended timeframe for the quad screen. Tests in this period are more focused on gestational diabetes screening and routine ultrasounds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The quadruple test is performed between 15-20 weeks of pregnancy to screen for chromosomal abnormalities and neural tube defects.

 

 

Easy to remember: In Down Syndrome, Beta hCG and Inhibin A are increases (B – Big; B in Beta hCG, B in Inhibin A)

 

*King Edward Abdicated his throne so all levels are decreased

choices.text: Take 2 pills the same day and continue
Continue pills and take extra precaution for 1 week

questions.text: A 23y woman who is using the combined oral contraceptive pill misses 2 pills in the 3rd week of the pack. What is the next best step? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Take 2 pills the same day and continue

 

Explanation:

 

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, the missed pill guidelines are –

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reassure and continue the packet: Simply continuing the packet without taking the missed pills would increase the risk of pregnancy.

 

Option C. Continue pills and take extra precaution for 1 week: This option is more applicable for missing three or more pills, where additional precautions and possibly emergency contraception might be necessary.

 

Option D. Start a new packet immediately: This approach is necessary only when three or more pills are missed in the third week, to avoid a pill-free interval and ensure continued contraceptive protection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If one or two combined oral contraceptive pills are missed in the third week, the woman should take the last missed pill as soon as possible, then continue the pack as scheduled, taking two pills in one day if necessary. This minimizes the risk of pregnancy.

questions.text: The long left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of which embryonic pharyngeal arch artery? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 6th arch

 

The long left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of the left 6th arch artery.

 

  • During embryonic development, the aortic arches give rise to several structures in the neck and chest.
  • The 6th arch artery, which is present on both the right and left sides, gives rise to the pulmonary arteries and the ductus arteriosus.
  • As the arch arteries regress and are replaced by the adult structures, the recurrent laryngeal nerves, which innervate the muscles of the larynx, become trapped behind the great vessels.
  • The distal 6th arch artery vanishes on the right side. The right recurrent laryngeal nerve is caught under the 4th arch artery, which becomes the future right subclavian artery, because there is no 5th arch artery.
  • On the left side, the 6th arch artery persists, which develops into ductus arteriosus, which later forms ligamentum arteriosum.
  • Due to the persistence of the 6th arch artery, the left recurrent laryngeal nerve is caught under it and therefore, has a relatively long course.
  • The left recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the aortic arch on its way to the larynx.
  • In the case of the long left recurrent laryngeal nerve, the nerve passes inferior to the ligamentum arteriosum, which is a remnant of the ductus arteriosus that is derived from the 6th arch artery.
  •  This can lead to an increased risk of injury to the nerve during surgical procedures involving the thorax or neck.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3rd arch:

 

  • Derivative: The 3rd pharyngeal arch artery contributes to the formation of the common carotid arteries and the proximal part of the internal carotid arteries.
  • Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve: It is not directly related to the course of the recurrent laryngeal nerve, and therefore, its persistence or anomalies don't affect the recurrent laryngeal nerve's course.

 

Option B. 4th arch:

 

  • Derivative: The 4th pharyngeal arch artery contributes to the formation of the left side into the arch of the aorta and on the right side into the right subclavian artery.
  • Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve: The recurrent laryngeal nerve, which arises from the vagus nerve, initially descends and then ascends around the 4th arch artery. However, this is not responsible for the long course of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Option C. 5th arch:

 

  • Derivative: Interestingly, in many cases, the 5th pharyngeal arch artery is rudimentary or even absent in humans. When present, it doesn't form any significant structures in the mature circulatory system.
  • Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve: Given its rudimentary nature, the 5th arch artery doesn't have a defined relationship with the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 6th pharyngeal arch artery contributes to the formation of the pulmonary arteries and the ductus arteriosus on the left side.

 

Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve: The left recurrent laryngeal nerve hooks under the ductus arteriosus (derived from the left 6th arch artery). In evolutionary terms, as the heart descended and the neck elongated during development, the nerve remained hooked around this artery, leading to its longer course on the left side. On the right side, the nerve hooks under the right subclavian artery (which isn't directly derived from the 6th arch but is related to its positioning). If there were a right-sided aortic arch (a rare congenital anomaly), the right recurrent laryngeal nerve would also have a longer course, similar to the left.

choices.text: Start IV fluids with large bore cannula
Needle decompression into the 5th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line
Take the patient to the ICU and intubate

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to the emergency department with respiratory distress and hypotension following a trauma. He has subcutaneous emphysema and there is an absence of air entry into the right side of the lungs. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Needle decompression into the 5th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line

 

History is suggestive of tension pneumothorax and hence immediate decompression is required to maintain hemodynamic stability. Definitive management involves insertion of Chest tube/Pigtail in the triangle of safety.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start IV fluids with large bore cannula: While IV fluids are important in managing hypotension, they do not address the immediate life-threatening issue of tension pneumothorax and might actually exacerbate the patient's condition by increasing venous return and further compressing the heart.

 

Option C. Take the patient to the ICU and intubate: Intubation in the setting of tension pneumothorax without prior decompression can worsen the patient’s hemodynamic status by increasing intrathoracic pressure.

 

Option D. Start positive pressure ventilation: Positive pressure ventilation could potentially increase the pressure in the pleural cavity, worsening the tension pneumothorax and leading to rapid hemodynamic deterioration.

 

Educational Objective:


In cases of tension pneumothorax, immediate needle decompression is critical to stabilize the patient and prevent further cardiovascular compromise. This emergency procedure is a life-saving intervention that precedes further definitive management like chest tube insertion.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Pneumothorax/ Chap 294

questions.text: A child was brought to the OPD complaining of swelling in the neck region, which moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. Which of the following is the correct treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sistrunk procedure

 

The clinical presentation of a neck swelling that moves with deglutition (swallowing) and protrusion of the tongue is highly suggestive of a thyroglossal duct cyst. This congenital anomaly arises from remnants of the thyroglossal duct, which can form cysts anywhere along the duct's path from the base of the tongue to the thyroid gland.

 

The definitive treatment for a thyroglossal duct cyst, whether it is inflamed, ruptured, or has formed a fistula, is the Sistrunk procedure. This surgical procedure involves the removal of the cyst along with the entire thyroglossal tract and a portion of the hyoid bone to prevent recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antibiotics: While antibiotics may be necessary if there is an infection, they do not treat the underlying cyst and would not prevent recurrence.

 

Option C. Incision and drainage: This approach may be used if there is an abscess formation, but it is not definitive treatment and would not prevent recurrence of the cyst or fistula.

 

Option D. Excision: Simple excision of the cyst alone is not sufficient as it does not remove the entire thyroglossal tract or part of the hyoid bone, leading to a high risk of recurrence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Sistrunk procedure is the definitive treatment for a thyroglossal duct cyst, involving the excision of the cyst, the entire thyroglossal tract, and part of the hyoid bone to ensure complete removal and prevent recurrence.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 38-year-old female who is experiencing substantial hair loss for 4 months and has a history of COVID-19 infection 8 months ago? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Telogen effluvium

 

  • The pattern of hair loss in this clinical scenario is telogen effluvium.
  • The condition described is characterized by the sudden onset of scalp hair loss, typically occurring one to two months after a triggering event, which may include high fever, infections (such as Cholera, Typhoid, or COVID-19), surgery, trauma, starvation, myocardial infarction (MI), pregnancy, or hemorrhage.
  • This type of hair loss is associated with an increase in the shedding of telogen club hairs due to the premature termination of the anagen proliferative phase of the hair cycle following a period of significant stress.
  • When telogen hair shedding lasts for more than six months, it is termed “chronic diffuse telogen hair loss.” The main causes of chronic diffuse telogen hair loss include thyroid conditions (both hyper- and hypothyroidism), severe iron deficiency anemia, acrodermatitis enteropathica, and malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Androgenetic alopecia: Typically presents as a patterned hair loss and is more gradual. It is driven by genetic factors and hormonal influences and does not usually have a sudden onset associated with illness.

 

Option C. Alopecia areata:

  • An autoimmune condition where the body's immune system attacks hair follicles.
  • It results in small, round, and smooth patches of hair loss, which can coalesce but often do not cause complete hair loss.

 

 

  • It's not directly linked to illnesses like COVID-19 and does not typically present as diffuse hair loss across the entire scalp as suggested in the question.

 

Option D. Trichotillomania:

  • A psychological condition where individuals compulsively pull out their own hair, leading to hair loss.
  • Hair loss pattern tends to be irregular with varied length hairs, and examination often reveals broken hairs.

 

 

 

  • The history provided does not suggest any compulsive behavior or the typical patchy, irregular pattern seen with trichotillomania.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Telogen effluvium is a form of non-scarring hair loss characterized by the diffuse shedding of hair resulting from the early entry of hair into the telogen phase (the resting phase of the hair cycle). This condition is often triggered by significant physiological stress, severe illness, or major life events.

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 89 page no 32.24, 32.39, 32.40, 86.17, 89.6, 89.14, 89.17, 89.20 89.24, 89.25, 89.46

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page 1509

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition 387

questions.text: A patient presents with a hypopigmented lesion on his back. On examination, there is a complete loss of fine touch and temperature sensation over the lesion. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leprosy

 

Leprosy, also known as Hansen's disease, is characterized by hypopigmented or erythematous lesions with a loss of sensation, which is a hallmark feature. The loss of fine touch and temperature sensation over the lesion indicates nerve involvement, which is typical of leprosy. Specifically, this question points towards tuberculoid leprosy, which is part of the Ridley-Jopling classification. Tuberculoid leprosy presents with a few well-defined hypopigmented lesions that have significant sensory loss due to nerve damage.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option  B. Cutaneous tuberculosis: This condition includes various forms such as lupus vulgaris, scrofuloderma, and tuberculosis verrucosa cutis. These typically present with different skin manifestations like plaques, nodules, or ulcers, not primarily hypopigmented lesions with sensory loss.

 

 

Option  C. Pityriasis alba: This condition commonly affects children and presents as multiple hypopigmented macules, often with fine scaling. There is no associated loss of sensation.

 

 

Option  D. Pityriasis versicolor: A superficial fungal infection caused by Malassezia species, presenting with hypo- or hyperpigmented patches with fine scaling. The condition does not cause loss of sensation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leprosy should be suspected in patients with hypopigmented or erythematous skin lesions accompanied by a loss of sensation, particularly fine touch and temperature. This sensory loss is due to peripheral nerve involvement, which is a characteristic feature of leprosy.

questions.text:
Which of the following are features of Korsakoff syndrome? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Confabulation
  2. Amnesia
  3. Peripheral neuropathy
  4. Ophthalmoplegia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

Korsakoff syndrome is a chronic memory disorder most commonly caused by severe deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). It is often associated with alcohol misuse, but can also be caused by other conditions. The primary features of Korsakoff syndrome include:

 

1. Confabulation: Patients often create false memories or stories to fill in gaps in their memory. These are not intentional lies, but rather attempts to make sense of their memory loss.

 

2. Amnesia: This involves significant memory impairment. Anterograde amnesia (difficulty forming new memories) is more prominent than retrograde amnesia (difficulty recalling past memories).

 

3. Peripheral neuropathy: This is also seen in Korsakoff syndrome, involving nerve damage that can cause pain, numbness, or weakness, typically in the hands and feet.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Ophthalmoplegia: This is not a feature of Korsakoff syndrome. Ophthalmoplegia, or paralysis of the eye muscles, is a characteristic of Wernicke's encephalopathy, which often precedes Korsakoff syndrome but is a separate condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Korsakoff syndrome is characterized by amnesia, confabulation, and peripheral neuropathy, but not ophthalmoplegia, which is associated with Wernicke's encephalopathy.

choices.text: Tissue factor

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factors would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in a patient on warfarin therapy?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Factor 2

 

Explanation

 

Factor 2 would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in a patient on warfarin therapy.

 

Factors II, VII, IX, X are vitamin k dependent coagulation factors, as their activated by carboxylation of their glutamate residues by enzyme y-glutamyl carboxylase requires vitamin K (reduced form) as a co-factor.

 

This reduced form of vitamin K is constantly oxidized for the reaction to continue. This recycling is done by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase. This enzyme is inhibited by warfarin. Thus, warfarin affects vitamin k dependent factors.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Factor 11: Incorrect, Factor XI is not vitamin K-dependent and thus not directly affected by warfarin therapy.

 

Option C. Tissue factor: Incorrect, Tissue factor (Factor III) is a different component of the clotting cascade that acts as a receptor and cofactor for Factor VIIa; it is not a vitamin K-dependent factor and is not affected by warfarin.

 

Option D. Factor 5: Incorrect, Factor V is not dependent on vitamin K for its function, so its activity is not diminished by warfarin therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warfarin therapy impacts the function of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors by inhibiting the recycling of vitamin K, crucial for the carboxylation of these factors. Factor 2 (prothrombin) is one of these affected factors, leading to a reduction in its clotting ability in the presence of warfarin, which is utilized therapeutically to prevent thrombosis.

questions.text: An electron microscopic picture of a cut section of a nerve fiber is given. What is the most commonly affected area in Guillain-Barre syndrome? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1  

 

The myelin sheath is most commonly affected in Guillain barre syndrome which is marked as 1 in the above image.

 

Guillain-Barre syndrome is acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP).

 

Infections with Campylobacter jejuni, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, and Mycoplasma pneumoniae, or prior vaccination, have been shown to have a significant epidemiologic association with Guillain-Barré syndrome.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • CSF: albuminocytologic dissociation (↑ protein with normal WBC count).
  • Nerve conduction studies: slowed conduction, conduction block.

 

Electron microscopy identifies an early effect on myelin sheaths. The cytoplasmic processes of macrophages penetrate the basement membrane of Schwann cells stripping away the myelin sheath from the axon. Ultimately, the remnants of the myelin sheath are engulfed by the macrophages. Remyelination follows the demyelination.

 

Label 2 – Axon:

 

  • This is the axoplasm or the central axon itself.
  • In axonal variants of GBS (such as Acute Motor Axonal Neuropathy, AMAN, and Acute Motor and Sensory Axonal Neuropathy, AMSAN), the axon is directly attacked, usually by antibodies against axonal membrane components (e.g., GM1, GD1a gangliosides).
  • However, these variants are less common than the demyelinating type (AIDP).
  • So while axonal involvement can occur (especially in severe or axonal variants), it is not the most common target.

 

Label 3 – Schwann cell nucleus:

 

  • Schwann cells make and maintain the myelin sheath in the peripheral nervous system.
  • In GBS, the immune system generally attacks the myelin sheath rather than directly killing Schwann cells or their nuclei.
  • Damage to Schwann cells may occur secondarily, but it is not the primary target.

 

Label 4 – Schwann cell cytoplasm:

 

  • Similarly, the Schwann cell cytoplasm (outside the myelin) is not the main target.
  • The immune attack focuses on the compact myelin (label 1).
  • Schwann cells help with remyelination later but are usually not directly destroyed.

questions.text: A patient has Bilateral right sided loss of vision. What is the most likely site of lesion. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Left optic tract

 

Given the description of "Bilateral right sided loss of vision," the most likely site of the lesion would be the  Left optic tract. This type of visual field loss is consistent with the right visual field information being interrupted after the optic chiasma, which would affect the right visual field in both eyes.The optic tracts carry visual information after it has crossed at the optic chiasma. A lesion in the left optic tract would lead to a loss of vision in the right visual field of both eyes (homonymous hemianopia). This is because the left optic tract carries information from the right half of the visual field of each eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right Optic Tract: Similarly, a lesion in the right optic tract would cause a loss of vision in the left visual field of both eyes. This is also homonymous hemianopia, but on the opposite side of the visual field loss compared to a left optic tract lesion.

 

Option C. Optic Chiasma: A lesion at the optic chiasma can cause various types of visual field defects. The most common is bitemporal hemianopia, which is the loss of the outer (temporal) halves of the visual field in both eyes. This typically occurs with pituitary tumors that compress the chiasma from below.

 

Option D. Optic Radiation: The optic radiation carries visual information from the thalamus to the visual cortex. A lesion in the optic radiation can also lead to homonymous hemianopia. The specific location within the optic radiation (e.g., Meyer's loop) can lead to more specific deficits like a superior quadrantanopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the visual pathway is critical for localizing lesions based on patterns of visual field loss. Lesions at different points along the visual pathway (e.g., optic nerves, chiasma, tracts, or radiations) will produce characteristic visual field defects. This knowledge is used to guide further diagnostic testing and management, which may include imaging studies like MRI or CT scans to visualize the lesion and determine its cause.

choices.text: Give continuous prophylaxis to the patient
Give prophylactic antivirals to the husband
Give antivirals whenever active lesions are present
Don't involve in intercourse when active lesions are present

questions.text: A female patient presents with active genital warts with a history of recurrence, but her husband doesn't have it. What advice will you give to prevent transmission? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Don't involve in intercourse when active lesions are present

 

  • This is the correct answer. Avoiding sexual contact when active lesions are present is one of the most effective ways to prevent the transmission of HPV.
  • Genital warts are primarily caused by specific types of human papillomavirus (HPV-6 and HPV-11).
  • These warts, also known as venereal warts or condyloma acuminata, are highly infectious and are commonly acquired through sexual contact.
  • However, they can also be transmitted through non-sexual means.
  • Genital warts are highly contagious when lesions are active, so abstaining from sexual activity during these times is crucial to prevent spread to partners.

 

 

Management of Genital warts:

 

  • Imiquimod and podophyllotoxin are the primary drugs recommended as first-line treatments for genital warts. Imiquimod stimulates toll-like receptors 7 and 8, inducing apoptosis in macrophages, monocytes, and dendritic cells.
  • Imiquimod cream is approved for the treatment of actinic keratoses, superficial basal cell carcinoma, and genital warts through topical immunomodulation
  • The most effective method to prevent the transmission of infection is to abstain from sexual intercourse when active lesions are present.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Give continuous prophylaxis to the patient.

 

  • This is not the correct approach because continuous prophylaxis with antivirals is not typically recommended for genital warts, which are caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV).
  • Antivirals are more commonly used for other viral infections like herpes simplex virus.
  • Moreover, prophylaxis doesn't prevent the transmission of HPV during periods without active lesions.

 

Option B. Give prophylactic antivirals to the husband.

 

  • This option is incorrect for similar reasons as option A. HPV, the virus causing genital warts, does not have a prophylactic antiviral treatment.
  • Furthermore, since the husband does not have active lesions or a history of genital warts, prophylactic treatment is not indicated.

 

Option C. Give antivirals whenever active lesions are present.

 

  • While this might seem like a reasonable approach, it is important to note that antivirals are not effective against HPV.
  • Treatment for active genital warts typically involves topical agents or procedures like cryotherapy, not systemic antiviral medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To prevent the transmission of genital warts caused by HPV, it is advisable to avoid sexual intercourse when active lesions are present, as there are no effective antiviral prophylaxis options for HPV, and HPV transmission risk is highest during periods with active lesions.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I Chapter 25 Page no 25.43

Illustrated synopsis of dermatology & sexually transmitted diseases page no 318

Robbins & Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 10 E page no 998

choices.text: Ultrasound showing streak ovaries and a small uterus
Ultrasound showing hepatomegaly with altered echotexture

questions.text: A 12-year girl is brought to the OPD by her mother. She is concerned that she is shorter than her peers. On examination there is ptosis on the right side, shield like chest and a webbed neck. On evaluation, which of the following is the most definitive finding? (NEET PG 2021 )
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ultrasound showing streak ovaries and a small uterus

 

Explanation:

 

Turner Syndrome:

 

  • Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder affecting females, characterized by the absence of all or part of one X chromosome (45,XO).
  • It presents with several distinct clinical features.

 

Clinical Features of Turner Syndrome:

 

  • Short stature: Typically shorter than peers, often the first noticeable symptom.
  • Primary amenorrhea: Due to streak gonads (non-functioning ovaries).
  • Shield-like chest: Broad chest with widely spaced nipples.
  • Webbed neck: Excess skin folds running from the tops of the shoulders to the sides of the neck.
  • Ptosis: Drooping of the upper eyelid, can be unilateral or bilateral.
  • Cardiac defects: Commonly coarctation of the aorta, though ventricular septal defects (VSD) can also occur but are less common.
  • Renal anomalies: Such as horseshoe kidney or a single kidney.
  • Other features: Low-set ears, high-arched palate, arms that turn outward at the elbows, narrow and turned-up fingernails and toenails, low hairline at the back of the head, receding or small lower jaw.

 

Ultrasound Findings:

 

  • The presence of streak ovaries (underdeveloped ovaries) and a small uterus are typical findings in Turner syndrome, leading to primary amenorrhea and infertility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ECHO shows VSD: While Turner syndrome can involve congenital heart defects, the most common cardiac anomalies are coarctation of the aorta and bicuspid aortic valve, not ventricular septal defect (VSD).

 

Option C. Ultrasound showing hepatomegaly with altered echotexture: This is not typically associated with Turner syndrome. Hepatomegaly might suggest liver disease or metabolic disorders, which are not characteristic of Turner syndrome.

 

Option D. Ultrasound showing single kidney: Renal anomalies can occur in Turner syndrome, such as a horseshoe kidney or a single kidney, but the primary findings expected include streak ovaries and a small uterus which are more specific for Turner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by a 45,XO genotype, primary amenorrhea, short stature, and distinctive physical features such as a webbed neck and shield-like chest. Ultrasound typically shows streak ovaries and a small uterus.

 

Ref: Page no 411, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: First line of treatment for glaucoma in adults is:(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PG analogues

 

These are typically the first choice for the long-term management of glaucoma due to their efficacy and favourable patient adherence factors.

 

Prostaglandin analogues are a class of medications used as the first-line treatment for glaucoma. They work by increasing the outflow of the aqueous humor from the eye, which lowers intraocular pressure. These drugs are preferred due to their effectiveness and once-daily dosing, which improves patient compliance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atropine: is a muscarinic antagonist and is not used for the treatment of glaucoma. It dilates the pupil, which can potentially worsen glaucoma, especially angle-closure glaucoma, by blocking the drainage of the aqueous humor from the eye.

 

Option C. Acetazolamide: is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. It reduces the production of aqueous humor in the eye, thereby reducing intraocular pressure. It is not typically the first-line treatment due to the potential for systemic side effects and the presence of more effective topical treatments.

 

Option D. Pilocarpine: is a cholinergic agonist that contracts the ciliary muscle and opens the trabecular meshwork, allowing for increased outflow of aqueous humor. It is not usually the first choice for the chronic treatment of glaucoma due to its frequent dosing and side effects but can be used in acute angle-closure glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line treatment for adult glaucoma is Prostaglandin Analogues, which are effective in lowering intraocular pressure with a convenient dosing schedule.

questions.text: Raise in ESR during pregnancy is due to? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fibrinogen

 

Explanation:

 

Pregnancy is characterized as a hypercoagulable state, and several changes occur in the coagulation system during pregnancy. One of the significant changes is the increase in fibrinogen levels, which leads to a rise in the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR).

 

Key Points:

 

  • Fibrinogen Levels: During pregnancy, fibrinogen levels increase by approximately 50%, from 200-400 mg/dL to 300-600 mg/dL. This rise in fibrinogen contributes significantly to the increased ESR.
  • ESR: The ESR can increase up to four times during pregnancy due to the increased levels of fibrinogen and globulin.
  • Platelet Count: There may be a slight fall in platelet count during pregnancy, commonly due to gestational thrombocytopenia, which is caused by hemodilution and increased platelet consumption. This condition usually has no adverse effect on pregnancy and is often observed in the third trimester.
  • Coagulation Factors: There is an increase in the plasma levels of several coagulation factors, including factors 1 (fibrinogen), 2, 7, 8, 9, and 10. Factors 2, 5, and 12 remain unchanged or mildly increased, while factors 11 and 13 are slightly decreased.
  • Clotting Time: Clotting time is generally unaffected by pregnancy.
  • Anti-Thrombin III: Levels of anti-thrombin III decrease during pregnancy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Albumin: Albumin levels typically decrease during pregnancy due to hemodilution, and they do not contribute to the rise in ESR.

 

Option B. Platelet: Platelet count may slightly decrease due to gestational thrombocytopenia, but this does not contribute to the rise in ESR.

 

Option D. Anti-thrombin antibody: This is not a relevant factor in the context of ESR increase during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The rise in erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) during pregnancy is primarily due to the increased levels of fibrinogen.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Pg59

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with a long-standing history of recurrent abdominal pain, nausea, and steatorrhea. The patient reports a significant history of alcohol abuse, and diagnostic imaging reveals signs of chronic pancreatitis. What is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Alcohol

 

Chronic alcohol consumption is the leading cause of chronic pancreatitis. Excessive alcohol intake can lead to repeated episodes of acute pancreatitis, eventually resulting in chronic inflammation, fibrosis, and loss of pancreatic function. Alcohol-induced chronic pancreatitis often presents with pain, malabsorption (leading to steatorrhea), and diabetes mellitus due to the destruction of insulin-producing cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gallstones: When they travel out of the gallbladder into the bile ducts, they can block the pancreatic duct, leading to inflammation of the pancreas, termed acute pancreatitis. While gallstones are a common cause of acute pancreatitis, they are not the predominant cause of chronic pancreatitis.

 

Option C. Autoimmune: Autoimmune pancreatitis (AIP) is a type of chronic pancreatitis caused by an autoimmune reaction against the pancreatic tissue. It can be part of the spectrum of IgG4-related disease. The pancreas may become enlarged and look like a tumor on imaging studies. AIP might present with jaundice, weight loss, and the aforementioned pancreatic enlargement. Treatment usually involves corticosteroids to suppress the immune response.

 

Option D. Drugs: Some drugs are known to cause pancreatitis. While the incidence is generally low, drug-induced pancreatitis can turn chronic if the offending medication isn't identified and discontinued. Common culprits include diuretics like furosemide and thiazides, certain antiretroviral drugs, and some antiepileptics like valproic acid, among others.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic alcohol consumption is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis, leading to repeated inflammation, fibrosis, and loss of pancreatic function over time.

questions.text:
Which of the following cells are present in the molecular layer of the cerebellum?(INICET MAY 2022)

 

1. Stellate cells

2. Basket cells

3. Purkinje cells

4. Granular cells
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 2

 

The molecular layer of the cerebellum contains stellate and basket cells.

 

The molecular layer is one of the three layers of the cerebellar cortex, along with the granular layer and the Purkinje cell layer. It is involved in the processing of sensory information, as well as motor planning and coordination. The stellate and basket cells within the molecular layer provide inhibitory feedback to the Purkinje cells, which are the only output neurons of the cerebellar cortex.

 

The parallel fibres, which originate from granule cells in the granular layer, run perpendicular to the Purkinje cell dendrites and provide excitatory input to the molecular layer. As the parallel fibres traverse the molecular layer, they make multiple synapses with the dendrites of Purkinje cells, where inhibitory synapses are formed. This allows the Purkinje cells to integrate the incoming excitatory and inhibitory signals and adjust their output accordingly.

 

Overall, the molecular layer plays a crucial role in the cerebellar circuitry and contributes to the precision of motor movements and balance.

 

 

1. Stellate cells:

  • Location: Stellate cells are present in the molecular layer of the cerebellum.
  • Function: These are inhibitory interneurons that primarily release GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) and inhibit the dendrites of Purkinje cells.
     

2. Basket cells:

  • Location: Basket cells are also located in the molecular layer of the cerebellum.
  • Function: These are another type of inhibitory interneuron. The axons of basket cells form "baskets" around the cell bodies of Purkinje cells, releasing GABA and inhibiting them.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Purkinje cells:

  • Location: Purkinje cells form their own distinct layer known as the Purkinje cell layer, which is situated between the molecular layer and the granular layer.
  • Function: These cells are the primary output neurons of the cerebellar cortex. They have large, flattened dendritic trees that extend into the molecular layer, receiving inputs from climbing fibers and parallel fibers. The axons of Purkinje cells send inhibitory projections to the cerebellar nuclei.
     

4. Granular cells:

  • Location: Granular cells are present in the granular layer, which is the innermost layer of the cerebellar cortex.
  • Function: These cells receive inputs from mossy fibers, which originate from various brainstem nuclei and the spinal cord. Granular cells send their axons into the molecular layer, where they bifurcate to form parallel fibers. These parallel fibers synapse onto the dendrites of Purkinje cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The molecular layer of the cerebellum primarily contains stellate and basket cells. This layer is one of three distinct layers of the cerebellar cortex and is crucial for integrating sensory and motor information to refine motor coordination and balance.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of Mollicutes? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ureaplasma urealyticum

 

Mollicutes is a class of bacteria distinguished by the absence of a cell wall.

 

They vary in form, although most have sterols that make the cell membrane somewhat more rigid.

 

Many are able to move about through gliding, but members of the genus Spiroplasma are helical and move by twisting.

 

The best-known genus in the Mollicutes is Mycoplasma. Colonies show the typical “fried-egg” appearance.

 

Mollicutes are parasites of various animals and plants, living on or in the host’s cells. Many cause diseases in humans, attaching to cells in the respiratory or urogenital tracts, particularly species of Mycoplasma and Ureaplasma. Phytoplasma and Spiroplasma are plant pathogens associated with insect vectors.

 

Ureaplasma urealyticum has the ability to hydrolyse urea. It causes non-gonococcal urethritis.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Orientia tsutsugamushi: This bacterium belongs to the family Rickettsiaceae and is the causative agent of scrub typhus, which is transmitted by mites.

 

Option C. Chlamydophila pneumonia: This bacterium belongs to the genus Chlamydophila, which is part of the Chlamydiaceae family. It causes respiratory infections.

 

Option D. Chlamydia trachomatis: This bacterium belongs to the genus Chlamydia, which is part of the Chlamydiaceae family. It causes various infections, including trachoma and sexually transmitted infections.

 

Educational Objective

 

Mollicutes is a class of bacteria distinguished by the absence of a cell wall. The most well-known genera in this class are Mycoplasma and Ureaplasma, with Ureaplasma urealyticum being a notable example that causes non-gonococcal urethritis.

questions.text: Sameer was tried in a court in the case of Sanjay’s murder in the park. Sahil appeared in court and stated that he saw Sameer with an axe in his hand while passing the park. What is this evidence known as? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Indirect

 

This type of evidence in known as an indirect evidence or circumstantial evidence.

 

This evidence providing only a basis for inference about the fact in dispute and it is not an eyewitness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hostile: Refers to a witness who is antagonistic or adverse to the party who called them to testify.

 

Option C. Direct: Evidence that directly proves a fact, such as an eyewitness account of the crime being committed.

 

Option D. Hearsay: Evidence based on what someone else said, not on the direct knowledge of the witness, and typically inadmissible in court due to its second-hand nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indirect or circumstantial evidence suggests a fact but does not directly prove it. In this case, seeing Sameer with an axe near the park suggests involvement but does not directly prove his guilt.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient with a confirmed diagnosis of mild to moderate Alzheimer's dementia has shown aversion and non-compliance to oral medications. The patient's caregiver reports difficulty in administering the oral drugs due to the patient's refusal to swallow pills. Considering the need for continued treatment, which of the following medications could be prescribed in a form that does not require oral administration?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rivastigmine

 

Rivastigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used in the treatment of mild to moderate dementia in Alzheimer's disease. Unlike memantine, donepezil, and galantamine, rivastigmine has the advantage of being available in a transdermal patch form. The transdermal patch allows for continuous delivery of the medication through the skin, which is beneficial for patients who are non-compliant with oral medications or have difficulty swallowing pills.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Memantine: Memantine is used in moderate to severe dementia and is usually administered orally. To date, there is no alternative route of administration available for memantine.

 

Option B. Donepezil: Donepezil is typically administered orally and is used in all stages of Alzheimer's disease. There is an orally disintegrating tablet form, but it still requires the ability to manage oral intake.

 

Option D. Galantamine: Galantamine is also used for mild to moderate Alzheimer's dementia and is administered orally. There is no non-oral formulation available for galantamine.

 

In conclusion, for a patient who refuses oral medication, rivastigmine can be prescribed in a patch form, providing an alternative route of administration that ensures the patient can continue to receive their dementia management therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with Alzheimer's dementia who refuses oral medication, rivastigmine can be prescribed in a transdermal patch form, providing an alternative route of administration that ensures the patient can continue to receive their dementia management therapy.

choices.text: Sexual abstinence for 3 months and avoid pregnancy for a year
Sexual abstinence for 3 weeks and avoid pregnancy for 6 months
Sexual abstinence for 6 weeks and avoid pregnancy for a year
Sexual abstinence for 6 months and avoid pregnancy for 6 years

questions.text: While discharging a patient who underwent a vesicovaginal fistula repair, which of the following would you recommend? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sexual abstinence for 3 months and avoid pregnancy for a year

 

Explanation:

 

  • Vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) is a type of urinary fistula that commonly arises due to obstetric trauma.
  • Small fistulas can heal spontaneously; however, most established fistulas require surgical repair.
  • The surgical repair is usually performed vaginally after approximately 3 months to allow inflammation to subside.
  • Post-operatively, continuous bladder drainage for 14 days along with antibiotics is recommended to facilitate healing.
  • Following VVF repair, it is recommended that the patient abstain from sexual activity for 3 months to allow the surgical site to heal properly and avoid complications.
  • Additionally, pregnancy should be avoided for a year to ensure the integrity and strength of the repair before subjecting the area to the stresses of pregnancy and childbirth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sexual abstinence for 3 weeks and avoid pregnancy for 6 months: This duration of abstinence is too short for the proper healing of the surgical site. Additionally, avoiding pregnancy for only 6 months might not provide sufficient time for the repair to gain adequate strength.

 

Option C. Sexual abstinence for 6 weeks and avoid pregnancy for a year: While the recommendation to avoid pregnancy for a year is appropriate, 6 weeks of sexual abstinence may still be insufficient for optimal healing of the fistula repair.

 

Option D. Sexual abstinence for 6 months and avoid pregnancy for 6 years: This recommendation is excessively long. While prolonged abstinence can prevent complications, a 6-month period is more than what is typically necessary. Similarly, avoiding pregnancy for 6 years is overly cautious.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Following vesicovaginal fistula repair, patients should be advised to abstain from sexual activity for 3 months and avoid pregnancy for a year to ensure proper healing and reduce the risk of complications.

 

Ref: Page 439, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: What is the substance used in PET scan? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  Fluoro-deoxy-glucose

 

This is a glucose analog where fluorine-18 replaces a normal hydroxyl group. FDG is taken up by cells, but unlike glucose, it is not metabolized, making it useful for imaging active tissues like cancer cells which metabolize glucose at high rates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tc99m pertechnetate: This is a radioactive form of technetium used primarily in the imaging of the thyroid gland and in nuclear medicine scans like the Meckel’s diverticulum scans. It is not used in PET scans.

 

Option C. Iodine-123: This isotope is primarily used in gamma imaging, particularly in thyroid studies, not in PET scanning.

 

Option D. Tc99-M: This refers to Technetium-99m, used widely in SPECT (Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography) imaging, not in PET scans.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Fluoro-deoxy-glucose (FDG) is the primary tracer used in PET (Positron Emission Tomography) scans to image metabolic activity of tissues.

questions.text: Which cardiac chamber enlargement is seen in the case of mitral stenosis on chest X-ray initially? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Left atrium

 

In the case of mitral stenosis (MS), the obstruction at the mitral valve leads to increased pressure in the left atrium as it works harder to pump blood through the narrowed valve. This increased pressure causes the left atrium to dilate. This dilation can be identified on a chest X-ray as enlargement of the left atrial silhouette. The left atrium enlargement is often the earliest and most prominent cardiac chamber change seen in mitral stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right atrium: Right atrium enlargement generally occurs later in the course of mitral stenosis as a consequence of the elevated pressure being transmitted back through the lungs to the right side of the heart.

 

Option C. Left ventricle: The left ventricle is typically not directly affected by mitral stenosis, as this condition primarily impacts the left atrium. Left ventricular enlargement would be more characteristic of conditions affecting the left ventricular outflow or volume overload.

 

Option D. Right ventricle: Right ventricular enlargement may eventually occur if the disease progresses to the point of causing pulmonary hypertension, which then puts a strain on the right ventricle. However, this is a later development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitral stenosis primarily leads to enlargement of the left atrium as the initial response to increased pressure upstream of the stenotic mitral valve. Recognition of this early sign on a chest X-ray can be crucial for diagnosing and managing mitral stenosis effectively.

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/VHD

questions.text:
What are the indicators that suggest CPR is of high quality? (INICET May 2023)

 

1. Chest compression at a rate of 100-120/minute

2. Breathing rate of 20-25/minute

3. Depth of compression should be 5-6 cm

4. Allow chest recoil
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 4 only

 

Explanation:

 

High-Quality CPR Indicators:

 

1. Chest Compression Rate: Chest compressions should be performed at a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute.

 

3. Depth of Compression: Compressions should have a depth of 5-6 centimeters (2-2.4 inches).

 

4. Chest Recoil: It is essential to allow the chest to fully recoil after each compression to ensure adequate filling of the heart between compressions. If an advanced airway, such as an endotracheal tube or supraglottic airway device, is in place, the recommended ventilation rate is 10 breaths per minute.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2, 3 only: While a compression depth of 5-6 cm is correct, a breathing rate of 20-25/minute is not part of the indicators for high-quality CPR.

 

Option C. 1, 2, 3, 4: Although chest compression rate, depth, and recoil are correct indicators, the breathing rate of 20-25/minute is not recommended for high-quality CPR.

 

Option D. 1 only: While the correct chest compression rate is part of high-quality CPR, other factors like compression depth and chest recoil are also crucial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Effective CPR involves chest compressions performed at a rate between 100 to 120 compressions per minute and at a depth of 5 to 6 centimeters, allowing the chest to fully recoil after each compression. The recommended compression-to-ventilation ratio is 30:2 without an advanced airway, and 10 breaths per minute if an advanced airway is in place.

choices.text: Cervical mucus thickening
Increase GnRH release

questions.text: Oral contraceptives act by all of the following mechanisms except: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase GnRH release

 

Explanation:

 

Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) function through several mechanisms to prevent pregnancy, but increasing the release of Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH) is not one of them. In fact, OCPs inhibit the release of GnRH.

 

Mechanisms of action of OCPs:

 

  • Inhibit ovulation: By suppressing the release of GnRH, and consequently, the pituitary secretion of Follicle Stimulating Hormone (FSH) and Luteinizing Hormone (LH), OCPs prevent the development and release of an ovum.
  • Prevent implantation: OCPs create a less favorable endometrial environment for implantation of a fertilized egg.
  • Cervical mucus thickening: OCPs increase the viscosity of cervical mucus, making it more difficult for sperm to enter the uterus and fertilize an ovum.
  • Produce static endometrial hypoplasia: OCPs cause the endometrial lining to remain thin, which further prevents implantation.
  • Affect tubal motility: OCPs can alter the motility of the fallopian tubes, reducing the likelihood of sperm meeting an ovum.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Inhibit implantation: OCPs prevent the endometrium from becoming suitable for implantation.

 

Option B. Cervical mucus thickening: OCPs increase the thickness of cervical mucus to block sperm penetration.

 

Option C. Inhibit ovulation: OCPs suppress the hormonal signals that trigger ovulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oral contraceptive pills prevent pregnancy by inhibiting ovulation, preventing implantation, thickening cervical mucus, producing static endometrial hypoplasia, and affecting tubal motility. They do not increase GnRH release; rather, they inhibit it.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition 485

questions.text: A young male child presented with gum bleeding and bow legs. Which vitamin deficiency is commonly associated with the described features? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ascorbic acid

 

ASCORBIC ACID DEFICIENCY

 

  • Scurvy is a clinical syndrome resulting from vitamin C (ascorbic acid) deficiency. 
  • Vitamin C is essential for the growth and repair of skin, cartilage, bone, and teeth.
  • Humans lack the active form of the enzyme L-gulonolactone oxidase required for synthesizing ascorbic acid, making it essential to acquire vitamin C from dietary sources or supplements. 
  • The primary cause of vitamin C deficiency is due to inadequate nutritional intake.
  • Histopathology:
    • Microscopic examination of affected tissues reveals evidence of compromised collagen synthesis.
    • In the skin, there is evident dermal disruption and atrophy, reduced number of collagen fibers, and they appear fragmented.
    • The affected area displays signs of dilated hair follicles, fibrosis, follicular hyperkeratosis, corkscrew hairs, and perifollicular hemorrhages. 
    • In the oral cavity, the gingival tissues exhibit hemorrhagic changes, characterized by capillary dilation and fibrin thrombi, subepithelial hemorrhages, and inflammatory infiltrates. 
    • Within the skeletal system, the osteoid matrix is thin and disrupted, accompanied by subperiosteal hemorrhages and indications of osteopenia.
  • Early oral signs visible in physical examination include gingivitis with bleeding, periodontal disease, loss of dentition.
  • About 80% of children with scurvy present with musculoskeletal signs and symptoms, including arthralgias, myalgias, hemarthroses, muscle hemorrhages, and subperiosteal hematomas.
  • Children might display a limp or resist bearing weight.
  • The knee joint is the most affected part of the body. 
  • Vitamin C deficiency can affect bone growth and development, leading to bone deformities like bow legs.
  • Another notable finding is the "scorbutic rosary," i.e., tender, angular, and sharp swellings at the costochondral junctions caused by weakened connective tissue.
  • Imaging studies may reveal the following:
    • Fractures and dislocations
    • Subperiosteal elevation
    • Alveolar bone resorption, osteopenia, or osteoporosis
    • Epiphyseal separation of the distal radius

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tocopherol: Vitamin E deficiency is extremely rare in humans as it is unlikely caused by a diet consisting of low vitamin E. Patients presenting early may show hyporeflexia, decreased night vision, loss/decreased vibratory sense; however, they have normal cognition. A more moderate stage of this deficiency may show limb and truncal ataxia, profuse muscle weakness, and limited upward gaze. Late presentations may show cardiac arrhythmias and possible blindness with reduced cognition. Ataxia is the most common finding. Patients that have abetalipoproteinemia have eye problems, often including pigmented retinopathy and visual field issues.

 

Option C. Calciferol: Vitamin D deficiency can lead to osteomalacia and rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults. The majority of patients with vitamin D deficiency are asymptomatic. However, even mild chronic vitamin D deficiency can lead to chronic hypocalcemia and hyperparathyroidism, which can contribute risk of osteoporosis, falls, and fractures, especially in older individuals. Patients with prolonged and severe vitamin D deficiency can experience symptoms associated with secondary hyperparathyroidism, including bone pain, arthralgias, myalgias, fatigue, muscle twitching, and weakness. Fragility fractures may result from chronic vitamin D deficiency, leading to osteoporosis. In children, irritability, lethargy, developmental delay, bone changes, or fractures can be symptoms of vitamin D deficiency.

 

Option D. Biotin deficiency: Biotin deficiency is very rare in those who take in a normal balanced diet. Nominal biotin deficiency has been noted in pregnant and lactating women, but its clinical significance is unknown. Dermal abnormalities in biotin deficiency include alopecia and periorificial dermatitis. Patients may also develop conjunctivitis and skin infections. Neurological symptoms include hypotonia, seizures, ataxia, numbness and tingling of the extremities, mental retardation, and developmental delay in children. The patient may show depression, lethargy, and a history of hallucinations. Other neurological abnormalities include optic atrophy and sensorineural hearing loss if the condition is left untreated. Intestinal symptoms may also develop such as nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. Other biotin deficiency presentations include ketoacidosis, lactic acidosis, and organic aciduria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gum bleeding and bow legs are seen with Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following drug binds to CD4 receptors and is used for both CCR-5 as well as CXCR-4 tropic HIV? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ibalizumab

 

Explanation: 


Ibalizumab is a post-attachment inhibitor that binds to CD4 receptors. After HIV attaches to CD4 via GP120, ibalizumab prevents the conformational change in the CD4 receptor that is necessary for viral entry. Since it acts directly on CD4 receptors, it is effective against both CCR5 and CXCR4-tropic HIV strains.


Entry Inhibitors

 

 

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Maraviroc: This is a CCR5 co-receptor antagonist. It only works against CCR5-tropic HIV and is ineffective against CXCR4-tropic strains.

 

Option C. Fostemsavir: This is an attachment inhibitor that binds to viral GP120, preventing initial attachment to CD4 receptors. It does not bind to CD4 receptors directly.

 

Option D. Tenofovir: This is a Nucleotide Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitor (NRTI). It works after viral entry by inhibiting viral DNA synthesis. It does not affect viral entry or bind to CD4 receptors.

 

Educational Objective: 


Ibalizumab is a post-attachment inhibitor that binds to CD4 receptors and prevents HIV from entering T-cells by inhibiting conformational changes required for interaction with CCR5 and CXCR4 co-receptors. It is useful in multidrug-resistant HIV cases where other entry inhibitors like Maraviroc (CCR5-specific) are ineffective.

questions.text: Identify the given ECG? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Torsade’s de pointes

 

Torsade’s de pointes is characterized by a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with varying QRS complex amplitudes and a twisting around the baseline.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Ventricular fibrillation: Characterized by a chaotic and irregular waveform without identifiable QRS complexes.
 

Option C. Atrial flutter: Shows a sawtooth pattern of atrial activity.
 

Option D. Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia: Shows uniform QRS complexes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Torsade’s de pointes are a type of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with a characteristic twisting pattern.

choices.text: Retinal pigmentation
Pale waxy disc
Narrowing of vessels
ERG – normal

questions.text: What among the following is not true about retinitis pigmentosa? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. ERG – normal

 

ERG is abnormal in retinitis pigmentosa.

 

  • Retinitis pigmentosa is a primary pigmentary retinal dystrophy predominantly affecting the rods more than the cones.
  • It is the most common hereditary fundus dystrophy, with the most common mode of inheritance being autosomal recessive.
  • In early disease, it shows reduced scotopic rod and combined responses, and photopic responses reduce with progression.
  • Eventually, the ERG becomes extinguished.
  • The characteristic visual symptom is night blindness, which may present several years before visible changes in the retina appear.
  • Dark adaptation is affected, and tubular vision may occur in advanced cases.
  • Fundus changes include bone-spicule retinal pigmentation, arteriolar attenuation, and 'waxy' disc pallor.

 

  • Visual field changes-
    • Annular or ring-shaped scotoma is a typical feature which corresponds to the degenerated equatorial zone of retina. As the disease progresses, scotoma increases anteriorly and posteriorly and ultimately only central vision is left (tubular vision). Eventually even this is also lost and the patient becomes blind.

 

  • Electrophysiological changes-

1. Electro-retinogram (ERG) is subnormal or abolished.

2. Electro-oculogram (EOG) shows absence of light peak.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Pale Waxy Disc: Optic disc pallor due to progressive degeneration.

 

Option C. Narrowing of Vessels: Attenuation of retinal arterioles due to retinal thinning and atrophy.

 

Option D.  ERG (Electroretinogram: ERG is not normal in retinitis pigmentosa. It shows abnormal findings, such as:

  • Early Disease: Reduced scotopic (rod) response and combined responses.
  • Progression: Reduced photopic (cone) responses.
  • Advanced Disease: ERG becomes extinguished or abolished

 

Educational Objective:

 

In retinitis pigmentosa, the ERG is not normal; it shows progressive abnormalities reflecting the degeneration of photoreceptor cells. Other features include retinal pigmentation, pale waxy disc, and narrowing of retinal vessels.
